title: Clinical Management of Co-Occurring Addictions

encoding: UTF-8

---

<div id="csl-bib-meta-6WC65APC" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-6WC65APC" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Lie et al. explore how personality disorders often coincide with addictions, particularly substance use disorders, and how this affects treatment. They emphasize the importance of using the ICD-11 classification system to better understand and manage these co-occurring issues. The authors explain that addictions frequently stem from harmful coping mechanisms linked to personality dysfunctions. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for creating effective treatment plans that involve multiple healthcare disciplines. The chapter provides guidelines for managing addictions based on the severity of personality dysfunction and specific personality traits. This approach aims to improve treatment outcomes by tailoring strategies to individual needs, making it relevant for healthcare providers working with patients facing these complex challenges.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-6WC65APC" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Co-Occurring Addictions, Substance Use Disorders, Personality Disorders, ICD-11, Clinical Management, Multidisciplinary Treatment
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-6WC65APC" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    Co-occurring addictions, especially substance use disorders, are common in individuals with personality disorder and can have huge impact on treatment course and outcome. The present chapter seeks to highlight the utility of the ICD-11 classification of personality disorders and related traits for understanding and managing co-occurring addictions. Addictions often arise from learned and reinforced dysfunctional coping patterns, which are at the core of personality dysfunction. Such understanding is deemed foundational for developing and maintaining an efficient multidisciplinary and integrated treatment plan for various kinds of addictions, which is elucidated in this chapter. The chapter specifically highlights guidelines for clinical management of addictions according to severity of personality dysfunction and individual trait domains.
  </article>
